author: @ladepechedumidi
title: ENTRETIEN. Jours fériés supprimés : "Ce que les Français refusent, c'est de perdre sans rien gagner en retour" - ladepeche.fr
text:
ENTRETIEN. Jours fériés supprimés : "Ce que les Français refusent, c’est de perdre sans rien gagner en retour"
La proposition de François Bayrou de supprimer deux jours fériés pour réduire la dette publique divise les Français. Entre attachement culturel, mémoire collective et enjeux économiques, la question dépasse largement le simple ajustement de calendrier. Le sociologue Jean Viard, auteur de Quand le tourisme s’éveillera, nous explique pourquoi toucher aux jours chômés reste un sujet sensible en France, et ce que cela révèle de notre rapport au temps.
Pour alléger la dette publique, François Bayrou a proposé de supprimer deux jours fériés. Parmi les dates évoquées : le lundi de Pâques et le 8-Mai. Derrière cette mesure budgétaire, un sujet sensible : attachement collectif, poids de l’histoire, équilibre des temps de vie… En France, les jours fériés ne se résument pas à une simple ligne dans le calendrier.
À lire aussi :
VRAI OU FAUX. La France est-elle vraiment championne du monde des jours fériés ?
La Dépêche du Midi : Pourquoi dit-on que les jours fériés sont "sacrés" pour les Français ? Est-ce vraiment le cas ?
Non, pas vraiment. D’abord, les Français n’ont pas plus de jours fériés que d’autres pays. En Espagne ou en Italie, il y en a même davantage notamment parce que les fêtes religieuses y sont plus nombreuses. En France, le catholicisme n’a pas la même place, donc ces jours sont moins nombreux et moins pratiqués. Mais il faut comprendre que le lundi de Pâques, par exemple, est essentiel pour le tourisme : le supprimer ferait perdre autant qu’il ferait gagner. En revanche, le mois de mai, avec tous ses ponts, casse le rythme du travail. Là, une réorganisation du calendrier aurait du sens.
À lire aussi :
Budget 2026 : François Bayrou veut supprimer deux jours fériés… Combien la mesure pourrait-elle rapporter ?
Quelle est l’origine de ces jours fériés ?
C’est l’Église qui a longtemps structuré le calendrier. Les jours chômés servaient à marquer le temps religieux. Avant la Révolution française, il y avait bien plus de jours fériés qu’aujourd’hui. La Révolution a voulu rompre avec cette emprise : elle a supprimé tous les jours fériés… y compris le dimanche. Ce n’est qu’en 1906 qu’on a rétabli ce dernier jour de la semaine non travaillé. La République a ensuite reconstruit un temps collectif : quelques fêtes catholiques ont été réintroduites, puis des dates militaires et républicaines sont venues s’ajouter au XIXe et au XXe siècle. Mais l’héritage religieux reste dominant. Il n’y a, par exemple, aucun jour férié juif ou musulman. Le calendrier n’est jamais neutre : il reflète des choix culturels, religieux et politiques.
À lire aussi :
Suppression de 2 jours fériés en 2026 : qu’en pensez-vous ?
Supprimer le 8-Mai ne risque-t-il pas de heurter la mémoire collective ?
Non pas du tout. Ce qu’il faut bien comprendre, c’est qu’il ne s’agit pas de supprimer la commémoration de la capitulation de l’Allemagne nazie, mais de travailler ce jour-là. Le 8-Mai peut rester un moment de mémoire sans être chômé. D’ailleurs, très peu de gens assistent aux cérémonies d'ancens combattants. Dans le contexte actuel de rapprochement avec l’Allemagne, cela peut aussi être interprété comme un geste symbolique fort. On ne renie pas le souvenir, on l’exprime autrement. On commémore bien l’affaire Dreyfus chaque 12 juillet sans que ce soit férié. Ce n’est pas l’absence de congé qui efface la mémoire.
À lire aussi :
Jours fériés : pourquoi le lundi de Pâques est-il chômé ?
Les Français travaillent-ils vraiment moins que les autres ?
Oui, c’est un fait incontestable. On travaille en moyenne 100 heures de moins par an que la plupart des pays européens. Mais ce n’est pas à cause des jours fériés. C’est surtout parce qu’on ne fait pas travailler les jeunes et qu’on sort trop tôt les seniors du marché du travail, dès 55 ans. Résultat : une partie active de la population ne produit pas. Si on rééquilibrait ça, par exemple en faisant travailler les étudiants un jour par semaine, on créerait énormément de richesse.
Faut-il repenser plus largement l’organisation du temps en France ?
Oui, c’est même une nécessité. Le cadre actuel, qu’il s’agisse du temps de travail ou du temps scolaire, date des années 1950. Il n’est plus adapté à la société contemporaine : ni aux 35 heures, ni au télétravail, ni aux nouveaux équilibres familiaux. Il faut tout remettre à plat : les vacances d’hiver, l’emploi des seniors, la place des étudiants dans l’économie… Et dans ce contexte, les jours fériés peuvent être mieux pensés. Le mois de mai, par exemple, n’est plus un mois de travail. Il y a trop de coupures, c’est devenu chaotique. Plutôt que de supprimer à la hâte, on pourrait imaginer un grand week-end fixe, bien placé, qui ferait consensus. Il faut proposer quelque chose de lisible et d'utile. Ce que les Français refusent, ce n’est pas le changement en soi.. C’est de perdre sans rien gagner en retour.

author: Jennifer Graham
title: ‘Certainly unexpected’: St. Augustine family welcomes baby just hours before Hurricane Milton’s landfall
text:
Jennifer Graham , WJXT Content Gatherer
Published: October 10, 2024 at 6:16 PM Tags: St. Augustine , Hurricane Milton , UF Health Flagler Hospital Hurricane Baby Nova (Copyright 2024 by WJXT News4JAX - All rights reserved.)
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. – One St. Augustine family will remember the day Hurricane Milton arrived much differently than many others, as they welcomed a new family member.
Katelyn Hicks and Christopher Washington welcomed Nova Reign Washington who made her arrival at UF Health Flagler Hospital, only a few hours before Milton landed on Florida’s west coast.
Recommended Videos
RELATED | Downtown St. Augustine businesses, homes spared after flood waters flow into historic city
The new bundle of joy weighed 7 pounds and one ounce at birth.
“Delivering our baby and then riding out a hurricane was not part of the plan and certainly unexpected,” Hicks said. “We watched the palm trees blowing from our hospital room window and felt safe the entire time. Nova let us sleep throughout most of the storm, thankfully.”
Hurricane Baby Family - Hurricane Milton (Copyright 2024 by WJXT News4JAX - All rights reserved.) Coincidentally, Nova’s 3-year-old sister is named Storm.
The family looks forward to telling Nova about her unique arrival in the future.
MORE | Disney World and other Orlando parks to reopen Friday after Hurricane Milton shutdown
“Our team is dedicated to providing high-quality care, no matter the weather, and we are thrilled to be able to celebrate a positive outcome at a time that is devastating for so many,” said Michelle Paulo, interim vice president of nursing.

title: Maduro ordena "acciones defensivas" ante la llegada de un buque británico a las costas de Guyana
text: Viajes y Lugares Tienda Siglo XXI Grupo Siglo XXI 19º ANIVERSARIO Fundado en noviembre de 2003 Opinión » Firmas y Blogs Viñetas Cartas Encuestas España Mundo Economía » Productividad Automóviles Empresas Deportes » Fútbol Baloncesto Tenis Motor Ciclismo Cultura » Cine Televisión y Medios Música Libros Sociedad » Moda y Tendencias Turismo y Gastronom. Ciencia » Salud Psicología Tecnología Mundo Maduro ordena "acciones defensivas" ante la llegada de un buque británico a las costas de Guyana Agencias @DiarioSigloXXI jueves, 28 de diciembre de 2023, 22:29 h (CET) Guyana afirma que no no llevarán a cabo "acciones ofensivas" contra Venezuela MADRID, 28 (EUROPA PRESS) El presidente de Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, ha ordenado este jueves a la Fuerza Armada Nacional Bolivariana (FANB) poner en marcha "acciones defensivas" ante la llegada de un buque de guerra británico a la costas de Guyana, en plena escalada de tensiones por la disputa territorial del Esequibo. Maduro ha anunciado que ha dado orden al conjunto de las Fuerzas Armadas para que active tanto en la zona oriental del Caribe como en la franja Atlántica una "acción conjunta de carácter defensivo" en respuesta a la "provocación" que supone la llegada de ese buque de guerra de la Marina británica. Es una "amenaza (...) contra la paz y la soberanía" de Venezuela, ha expresado el mandatario durante su intervención con motivo del fin de año, emitida por la cadena de radiotelevisión venezolana. El vicepresidente de Guyana, Bharrat Jagdeo, ha asegurado que el país no tienen intención de llevar a cabo "acciones ofensivas" contra Venezuela y ha recordado que la llegada del buque forma parte de un ejercicio militar "rutinario" planeado desde hace "mucho tiempo". "Nada de lo que hacemos o hemos hecho amenaza a Venezuela", ha recalcado durante una rueda de prensa, aseverando que Guyana está comprometida con la Declación de Argyle firmada entre las partes el pasado mes de diciembre, ha recogido el portal de noticias Newsroom. Horas antes, el Ministerio de Asuntos Exteriores de Venezuela había emitido un comunicado de rechazo a la llegada de la Armada Británica a Guyana, en un momento en que las relaciones entre Caracas y Georgetown no pasan por su mejor momento debido a un aumento de las tensiones en su ya recurrente disputa por el Esequibo. "La presencia de la nave militar es extremadamente grave, ya que viene acompañada de declaraciones por parte de portavoces políticos y militares de que quien fungió como despojador de la Guayana Esequiba", dice el comunicado haciendo referencia a Reino Unido como potencia colonial. La disputa entre Venezuela y Guyana por el Esequibo data de hace casi dos siglos, si bien ha sido hace cinco años con el descubrimiento de importantes yacimientos petroleros bajo sus aguas cuando se reavivó el conflicto. Ambos países están enredados en una disputa por 159.000 kilómetros cuadrados de territorio al oeste del río Esequibo, una región rica en petróleo, minerales y biodiversidad que a menudo aparece en los mapas venezolanos como zona de reclamación y que constituye dos tercios de la superficie total de Guyana. El llamado Laudo Arbitral de París de 1899 fijó los límites marcados por Londres, a los que se agarra Guyana, su antigua colonia. A mitad del siglo XX se descubrió un supuesto arreglo político para influir en el voto de uno de los juristas en dicho arbitraje, por lo que Venezuela reavivó la cuestión. Así, en 1966, en pleno contexto de descolonización y tres meses antes de la independencia de Guyana, Caracas y Londres firmaron el hoy vigente Acuerdo de Ginebra, que reconoce las demandas venezolanas. author: Pembroke Pines
title: Baptist Health breaks ground on new Pembroke Pines facility
text:
PEMBROKE PINES, Fla. – Baptist Health is building a new medical center in Pembroke Pines and it broke ground on the facility Wednesday.
The nearly 61,000-square-foot, three-story facility will offer inpatient and outpatient care.
It will feature a freestanding emergency department and will bring together specialties from brain and spine care, heart and vascular care and primary care, all in one location.
“We’ve been part of here in Broward County for many years and really now it’s bringing our specialties our medical specialties and that access to care that’s so important with a freestanding emergency department and really having that coordination of care that you can have all of these services under one roof and really bringing convenience to the patient,” Baptist Outpatient Services CEO Nancy Batista-Rodriguez said.
The new facility is set to open in early 2027.

author: @ManchInkLink
title: A boomer’s tribute to those we lost in 2023 | Manchester Ink Link
text: O P I N I O N It’s that time of the year when we recognize and remember those we’ve lost this past year. All of the news organizations will again pay tribute to individuals we’re all familiar with like Norman Lear, 101; Henry Kissinger, 110; Rosalynn Carter, 96; Matthew Perry, 54; Dianne Feinstein, 90; Bob Barker, 99; Paul Reubens, 70; Tony Bennett, 96; and Alan Arkin, 89. Some of those who have passed this year may not be familiar to everyone, but they may have been important to us as we matured. To those, I give special thanks for what they contributed to my own experiences. [Denny Laine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denny_Laine), 76, December 5. Laine was a founding member of The Moody Blues, 1964-1966, singing their hit cover version of “Go Now.” According to legend, while the Moody Blues were on tour with [The Beatles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Beatles)in 1965, Laine met [Paul McCartney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_McCartney), who later asked him to join his band Wings. Laine played guitar, bass, and keyboards, and sang backup and lead vocals with Wings during its entire run, 1971 to 1981. He also co-wrote songs with McCartney including the 1977 hit “ [Mull of Kintyre.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mull_of_Kintyre_(song))” The Moody Blues and Wings are on my own favorite rock groups list. - Suzanne Somers, 76, October 15. Somers was perhaps best known for what was termed “T and A” television as Chrissy Snow in Three’s Company, 1977-1981, and pitching the ThighMaster. She was also a breast cancer advocate and health and wellness businessperson and she wrote more than 25 books, including two autobiographies, four diet books, and a book of poetry. Who knew? - Having lived in Boston for more than 40 years, how could I not remember Red Sox Tim Wakefield (57, October 1), our [knuckleball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knuckleball) [legend](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitcher)? Although he began his MLB career with the Pittsburgh Pirates, he will always be most remembered for his 17 years with the [Red Sox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Red_Sox). Wakefield was the longest-playing player on the team (1995-2015). When he retired at age 45 after 19 seasons in MLB, Wakefield was the oldest active player in the major leagues. - David McCallum, 90, September 25. Do you remember watching [The Man from U.N.C.L.E](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Man_from_U.N.C.L.E.). as a kid? In the ’60s, secret agents were all the craze and we couldn’t get enough of them. I, like so many, preferred agent [Illya Kuryakin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illya_Kuryakin)over the suave Napoleon Solo (Robert Vaughn). While playing Kuryakin, McCallum received more fan mail than any other actor in [Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer)‘s history. In 2003 McCallum again reinvented his popularity playing Medical Examiner [Dr. Donald “Ducky” Mallard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_NCIS_characters#Dr._Donald_.22Ducky.22_Mallard) in the television series [NCIS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCIS_(TV_series)) for 20 seasons until his death. Twenty years. Who knew? - Terry Kirkman, 83, September 24. You may not know his name, but you have to know the song he wrote, “ [Cherish,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cherish_(The_Association_song))” as a member of [The Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Association)that has been played at innumerable wedding ceremonies. According to [BMI](https://www.bmi.com/news/entry/19991214_bmi_announces_top_100_songs_of_the_century)(Broadcast Music, Inc.), “Cherish” was the 22nd most-played song of the 20th Century. Was “Cherish” played at your wedding? - When you hear the name Gary Wright, (80, September 4), don’t you automatically start singing the song “ [Dream Weaver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dream_Weaver)“? Okay, maybe you don’t. But perhaps you recall his 1976 hit “ [Love Is Alive.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Love_Is_Alive_(Gary_Wright_song)). Prior to “Dream Weaver,” Wright spent seven years as a member of the British band [Spooky Tooth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spooky_Tooth)and as a solo artist. While in England, he played keyboards on former [Beatle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Beatles) [George Harrison](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Harrison)‘s triple album [All Things Must Pass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Things_Must_Pass)(1970). - Randy Meisner, 77, July 27, founding member of the ’70s rock band the [Eagles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eagles_(band)). Meisner was a [bassist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bassist)and a high-harmony vocalist as an Eagles group member and session musician. He co-wrote and sang the lead vocal on the Eagles hit song “ [Take It to the Limit.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Take_It_to_the_Limit_(Eagles_song))” I can hear you start humming now. - Perhaps the best-known of this group is Jimmy Buffett, 76, who died September 1. Buffett, himself, called his [music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Buffett#cite_note-13)“drunken Caribbean rock ‘n’ roll.” “It’s pure escapism is all it is…I’m not the first one to do it, nor shall I probably be the last. But I think it’s a part of the human condition that you’ve got to have some fun. You’ve got to get away from whatever you do to make a living or other parts of life that stress you out. I try to make it at least 50/50 fun to work and so far it’s worked out.” —Jimmy Buffett Buffett recorded many hit songs known as “ [The Big 8,](https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2023-09-02/12-essential-jimmy-buffett-songs)” including “ [Margaritaville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaritaville)” (1977), ranked 234th on the Recording Industry Association of America‘s list of “ [Songs of the Century](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Songs_of_the_Century)“; “ [Come Monday](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Come_Monday)” (1974); “ [Fins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fins_(song))” (1979); “ [Volcano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volcano_(Jimmy_Buffett_song))” (1979); “ [A Pirate Looks at Forty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Pirate_Looks_at_Forty)” (1974); “ [Cheeseburger in Paradise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheeseburger_in_Paradise)” (1978); “ [Why Don’t We Get Drunk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Why_Don%27t_We_Get_Drunk)” (1973); and “ [Changes in Latitudes, Changes in Attitudes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Changes_in_Latitudes,_Changes_in_Attitudes_(song))” (1977). He also performed “ [It’s Five O’Clock Somewhere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/It%27s_Five_O%27Clock_Somewhere)” with [Alan Jackson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Jackson) (2003). Although he only had one Top 10 song, 1977’s “Margaritaville” became his [signature](https://www.cnn.com/2023/09/02/entertainment/jimmy-buffett-death/index.html). The chorus has been part of countless singalongs (Come on, now, sing along): “Wasted away again in Margaritaville, searching for my lost shaker of salt… Some people claim that there’s a woman to blame, but I know, it’s my own damn fault.” As one of the world’s richest musicians, Buffett had a [net worth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Net_worth) of $1 billion and he was a bestselling author. You can bump into many of his fans, or “ [Parrotheads,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Buffett#cite_note-state-21)” at Latitude Margaritaville, his three retirement communities located in Daytona Beach and Watersound, Florida, and Hilton Head, South Carolina. You may also be familiar with his other business ventures, including [Jimmy Buffett’s Margaritaville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Buffett%27s_Margaritaville) restaurant chain, the now-defunct [Cheeseburger in Paradise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheeseburger_in_Paradise_(restaurant)) restaurant chain, and enterprises in hotels, casinos, and liquor. With the end of 2023, let’s raise a glass and toast these individuals and others we lost who were so meaningful to us. Cheers.

author: deccanchronicle.com
title: DC Edit | A win for women’s rights, secularism, thanks to SC
text:
DC Edit | A win for women’s rights, secularism, thanks to SC DC Comment DC Comment 11 July 2024 6:57 PM GMT x Supreme Court of India, where a historic verdict was delivered, upholding the rights of Muslim women to seek alimony under secular laws. (DC File Image) The Supreme Court’s verdict asserting that Muslim divorcees are not bound by the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Divorce) Act, 1986, while seeking alimony from their former husbands and that this law will not prevail over Section 125 of the erstwhile Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) reassures the primacy of the secular laws in a country that chose to be secular despite its Partition along religious lines.
The verdict, which has legal and political overtones, becomes historic for several reasons. Primarily, it has brought into focus the dignity of human life and ruled that maintenance is not charity but the right of all married women, irrespective of their religion. It also effectively neutralises the 1986 law, brought in to overturn the apex court ruling in 1985 in the famous Shah Bano case which allowed Muslim women to seek maintenance under the secular law. With the latest order, the legal recourse a Muslim woman had to take to get her rightful relief has been restored.
The 1986 law had sought to bar Muslim women from accessing the reliefs available to all Indian women. It marked an inflection point in Indian politics after which matters took a turn for the worse. Congress Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, who came to power with an unprecedented 414 seats in the 543-member Lok Sabha in the 1984 election, allowed himself to be tricked into introducing this law which undermined the secular credentials of not only his party but also of the country. The Prime Minister was unable to foresee the damage such a regressive law could cause to the social fabric of the country.
The charge that the Congress had sold itself to Muslim fundamentalists gave an extra push to Hindutva politics, championed by the BJP, and was followed by the opening of the gate of the Babri Masjid locked up in 1949 on the orders of then Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru. Tumultuous events followed, starting with the Rath Yatra of Mr Lal Krishna Advani, followed by the razing of the Masjid, and ultimately, the construction and consecration of the Ayodhya Ram temple. The Congress and secular politics ended up the losers.
Now, India is back to square one. The Supreme Court has rendered this divisive law toothless by declaring that it is up to the aggrieved Muslim woman to seek remedy under the provisions of either law — the Section 125 of the CrPC or the 1986 law. It has also held that the 1986 law did not negate the CrPC, which is religion-neutral; it only added to the choices of the Muslim women. In fact, courts across India had offered Muslim women relief under the CrPC despite the presence of the 1986 law in the statute book. The latest order only places on it the imprimatur of the Supreme Court.
India, a nation with limited resources, has to wage a tough battle in order that it may ensure a dignified life for all its citizens. Communal angles to social issues can only undermine or delay those efforts. The SC order reminds all stakeholders to stay the course.
( Source : Deccan Chronicle )
